Legal_Issue: Interpretation of residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act and consideration of relevant criteria
Application_Facts: Mr. Chen was absent from Canada for 970 days, citing care for his ill mother and religious purposes
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; Mr. Chen remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge's decision was reasonable
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in interpretation of residency requirement and failure to consider humanitarian factors
Assessment_Factor: Koo factors, family ties, nature of absences, centralization of mode of existence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court challenging administrative decision
Credibility_Assessment: Absences deemed structural and voluntary, not humanitarian
Evidence_Used: Duration and purpose of absences, family circumstances, religious activities
Application_Basis: Requirement to centralize mode of existence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicants must meet physical presence and residency requirements under the Citizenship Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate that absences were due to humanitarian or compelling reasons
Harm_Assessment: No harm established due to lawful application of residency rules
Cause_Description: Denial of citizenship due to non-compliance with residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Consideration of Koo factors and personal circumstances
Evidence_Issues: Absences not supported as involuntary or humanitarian
Residency_Compliance: Not met â€“ 970 days of absence
Evidence_Assessment: Absences evaluated as voluntary and not exceptional
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the law and considered relevant factors
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of evidence characterizing absences as non-voluntary
